views.description: The real axis with trivial zeros and other interesting points.
The only singularity of ζ(s). A simple pole with residue 1, where the function explodes to infinity.
ζ(0) = -1/2. This mysterious value connects to the sum of a divergent series 1+1+1+... via analytic continuation.
ζ(−1) = −1/12. This staggering result suggests the sum of all natural numbers is −1/12. It is a cornerstone of String Theory and the Casimir Effect.
ζ(2) = π²/6 ≈ 1.645. Euler's 1734 solution stunned the mathematical world.
ζ(3) ≈ 1.202. Proven irrational by Roger Apéry in 1978, still mysterious today.
ζ(−2) = 0. Trivial zeros arise from sin(πs/2) in the functional equation. 'Trivial' because their existence is easily proven.  All negative even integers are zeros—infinitely many."
The strip 0 < Re(s) < 1 where all non-trivial zeros reside.
Riemann Hypothesis claims all non-trivial zeros reside not just within the critical strip but on the line Re(s) = 1/2.
The first real zero of the derivative ζ'(s). Exploring these points helps mathematicians understand the distribution of the function's values.
Where ζ'(s) = 0. Unlike zeros, saddle points are not perfectly symmetric around the critical line but come with pairs.
The first non-trivial zero, found by Riemann in 1859. It confirms the Zeta function's link to the distribution of primes.
Where Im(ζ(1/2+it)) = 0. Gram points bracket some zeros and help locate them.
Its distance from the first zero (~6.89) began the study of 'spectral gaps' in number theory.
The second Gram point, used in computational verification of zeros.
Part of the original set that suggested all non-trivial zeros lie on the Critical Line (Re=1/2).
Exhibits the irregular, 'random matrix' behavior typical of complex quantum systems.
Part of an unusually tight cluster, demonstrating that zeros do not appear at regular intervals.
Confirmed by G.H. Hardy in 1914, proving infinitely many zeros exist on the critical line.
Marks the boundary of what 19th-century mathematicians could verify through manual calculation.
A cluster of consecutive zeros showing the irregular spacing pattern.
An example of 'level repulsion,' where zeros rarely get too close, similar to energy levels in atoms.
Higher zeros like this one 'fine-tune' the error term in the Prime Number Theorem.
Calculated by J.P. Gram (1903), who developed methods to predict zero locations.
The symmetry ζ(s) ↔ ζ(1−s) reflects the function across the critical line.
The first violation of Gram's Law. Here, the expected alternating rhythm of zeros and Gram points breaks down, showing the underlying chaotic nature of the function.
Two zeros at t≈7005.063 and t≈7005.101 separated by only 0.038. ⚠️ Beyond shader precision limits—rendering is approximate. True visualization requires extended precision arithmetic.
